dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Have you started any projects yet, or that's?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I am just starting one right now.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What's it on?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I'm trying to figure out how stars in the galaxy are moving based on what they're made of, which is interesting.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh, clearly, time comes in to what you're doing. To what extent do you have to grapple with some of the subtle features of time?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, with my research in particular, I've really want to know what happened in the past and what happened in the future, but you only get a single snapshot when you look up at the night sky.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right, but if it's sufficiently far back, you're--

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Great, and so we can learn a lot by looking at other galaxies and seeing what they were doing in their present, I suppose.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Just figuring out what's gonna happen next is part of the issue. That's looking into the future, I suppose.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And so have you taken general relativity, or you taken that now, or?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I took a course on general relativity, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But you learned about black holes?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Sure.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: One of the weird things and wonderful things about wormholes is that they are tunnels, if you will, shortcuts from one point in space to another point in space. But once you have a shortcut from here to there, the beautiful thing is, if you move the openings, time will elapse differently at the different openings. So there's a possibility of wormholes as time machines. Go one direction, you're going into the future, go the other direction, you'd be going into the past. But that, of course, raises philosophical and logical--

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Paradoxes.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: yeah, absolutely.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: paradoxes and sort. So what do you think, what do you?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I throw it to you.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, I've heard a few different theories that people posit. Like maybe it is back to the future, and you really change your own universe. I've also heard people say that you could have multiple universes spawned from this event or something along these lines.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, if you are going to be able to change the past, that's the one that resonates most with me.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think the same.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, so you go into the past, and maybe you can prevent your parents from meeting, but you're preventing them from meeting in the parallel reality, which means that you will never be born in that reality, but the origin of your birth is still completely understood, it was in the universe from which you originated. Another one that's more subtle is, the laws of physics may prevent you from interceding.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And that raises uncomfortable issues for many people having to do with like free will.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I'm immediately uncomfortable.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, so that one, there's actually some people like Joe Polchinski who did some wonderful studies of billiard ball tables, where you imagine a billiard ball goes into a wormhole, comes out and hits the very ball that was going into the hole. And in that way, if it could knock it off course, we seem to be in some logical paradox.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Absolutely.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: But the finding was, the ball can come out and just sort of graze the other one, but it can't affect it enough to prevent the sequence of events from happening. And the way I like to think about it frankly is if there's one universe, not parallel universes like in the other solution, moments in time just are. They don't change, the whole point of time is the variable along which change can happen. So if you have the atoms of time, the individual events, there's no conception of them changing. So whatever collection of influences were in play that allowed your parents to meet, they will always be in play because you were always part of that moment.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Do you think travel back to the past is impossible because of a deep physical, like mathematical reasoning, or just because of all of these problems that yet you've been talking about?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I suspect that when we've fully understand the mathematics of the final physical laws, if we ever come upon them, I think there's gonna be something built in that prevents this kind of free travel to the past. But sometimes I wonder if that's just coming from a more emotional place where I sort of want the world to be safe from this kind of paradoxes. So what's pretty clear based on any of the hypothetical proposals for traveling to the past that have come out of physics, you can't travel to a moment in the past before the first time travel machine is built.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Sure, you know the twin paradox?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Where, you know, you fly off, looks like you're moving fast, but to you, it looks like the other guy's moving fast so who actually ages more? Who ages less?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: What if, say, the universe isn't flat? What if the universe is curved, and you go off in one direction and then you come back in the same direction, you pass by the Earth, who's older then? Do we have an answer?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, we do have an answer. So the simplest version of that is, imagine that the universe has a shape of a donut.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And imagine I turn on two laser beams, sending a beam of light going to my right and to my left. And these beams will go around the entirety of space, and they'll both come back, and at some point, they will hit me. Imagine they hit me at the same moment from my perspective. Now imagine someone's moving relative to my frame of reference, say, to my left, they do the same experiment. They fire the beam of light left and right. Notice that the beam that they fire to their left will have to travel farther to reach them because they're moving away from it. Whereas the beam that they fired to their right will not have to travel as far because in some sense, they're moving toward it. The two beams of light will not hit that moving observer at the same moment.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: To you or to them?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: To them.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Wow.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Which means that there's a preferred frame of reference in this universe. Everybody is not on equal footing

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Fascinating.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: as they are when we teach to freshmen the special theory of relativity. That's right, exactly.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Me, for example.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: No, everybody else is moving relative to me, and it's real motion. So everybody else will be like the moving twin. They will be younger and I will be older. And when you think about past and future on a cosmological scale, there was a long period when there were no human beings in the universe. The fact of the matter is there will be these two long stretches with our presence being sort of a flicker in between, does that thought inform anything about how you live in your brief flicker within that brief flicker?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I rage against thinking like that.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Too defeatist?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think it's too defeatist. I think that's the perfect way to put it. Because it might be a brief flicker on a single moat of dust like floating in a cosmic eternity.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yep.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: But it's everything. There's nothing else that I'll ever experience. And so in a way, there's nothing else to me.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: There's an eternity, but I'm never gonna see it, I'm never gonna feel it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: It can be debilitating to imagine an eternal future of sort of nothing, where none of what we do sort of persist. On the other hand, if you flip your perspective around and say, How remarkable is it that we have this brief moment that allows us to think and feel and love and explore and illuminate, wow, how wonderful is that?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.
